This fixed abode in a state, first the state is clearly manifested.
The commentary says:
Just as in the state of milk, milk is also not just that.
In this state, it is extinguished, as explained before, because the two dharmas of existence and non-existence contradict each other.
Moreover, the verse says:
Fixed abode in a different state, first the state has already ceased.
The commentary says:
In this way, if there is something that changes in the state of fixed abode in difference, like the state of curds, there is no separate cessation.
Why is it so?
When curds have already been formed, milk does not arise again.
Here, the fixed loss of sequence is because the different states have no different natures.
If it is said that the substance of things does not cease, this is contradictory.
Or if one conceives that cessation has something to be attained, that is not reasonable. Now, I will refute that.
Since other dharmas have no arising or abiding to be refuted, one's own dharma is also non-existent.
The cessation that is now spoken of is because one's own dharma does not exist.
Moreover, a verse says:
Just as the characteristics of arising of all dharmas cannot be apprehended,
The cessation of all dharmas can also not be apprehended.
The commentary says:
What does this mean?
If there is a dharma of cessation in all places, then it is not real.
Moreover, a verse says:
If a dharma exists, cessation cannot be apprehended.
In one place, the two natures of existence and non-existence cannot coexist.
The commentary says:
Because they contradict each other.
Moreover, a verse says:
Without dharma, there is no effect. Cessation can also not be apprehended.
Just as without a second head, one cannot say it is cut off.
Someone says:
Relying on the essence of cessation.
Here, wanting to make cessation something that can be attained, the verse answers:
Dharmas do not cease by their own essence, nor do they cease by the essence of another;
Just as arising does not arise by itself, nor does it arise by the essence of another.
If this cessation has not yet ceased, its own essence would be able to cease;
If this cessation has already ceased, having ceased, what is there to cease again?
If this cessation is different, cessation would be an infinite regress;
If cessation has nothing to cease, all dharmas would cease in this way.
Or the author says:
If the dharma of arising is refuted, the self-nature of dharmas is said to have the fault of opposition, namely, in the ultimate truth there are conditioned dharmas opposed to the unconditioned.
Now, in response to that, the verse says:
Arising, abiding, and ceasing are not established, so there are no conditioned dharmas;
If conditioned dharmas are not established, how can there be the unconditioned?
The commentary states:
This is said to be ultimately arisen from the perspective of dependent origination.
For example, a barren woman does not give birth to a child, and the substance of worldly things is not established.
Here, a question should be asked:
If there are no conditioned phenomena and characteristics of conditioned phenomena, how did the World-Honored One speak of the three characteristics of conditioned phenomena?
Therefore, the verse responds:
Like a dream, like an illusion, like a gandharva city,
The arising, abiding, and ceasing that are spoken of are also like this.
The commentary states:

All phenomena are like dreams, illusions, and gandharva cities, which are all the nature of the realm of discriminating cognition. Therefore, the appearances of elephants, horses, carriages, infantry, men, women, countries, cities, and so forth are all empty in essence.

Therefore, all phenomena such as arising and so forth are all that which is produced by the nature of the realm of cognition. In ultimate truth, they are not established as having substance, because their self-nature is empty.
Therefore, the Buddha wishes to enable beings to abandon the view of permanence regarding conditioned phenomena and attain liberation. He thus states that there is no birth, aging, etc.
What is called old is also not old.
This contradicts his own statement of having attained something.
Therefore, the verse says:
Oldness is not apart from oldness, oldness does not exist at the time of oldness;
This nature of oldness is not established, and neither is the nature of other things.
Therefore, oldness cannot be attained within a single dharma;
Oldness is not old by itself, nor by the nature of another.
This oldness does not make itself old, and it is the same for all old things;
If oldness has a separate nature, oldness would be endless.
Liberation, escape, and the path are also like this, complete in themselves;
If a dharma is apart from its own characteristic, its effect cannot be attained either.
The commentary says:
As it is said about liberation, all wholesome dharmas are called the causal condition.
If the nature of good dharmas is something that can be obtained, how can it be said to be the causal condition?
If so, then those consciousnesses and so forth can also be said to be causal conditions and have something that can be obtained.
Why is this?
Because they have no substance in the nature of distinctions, and the nature of distinguished consciousnesses is also not their own essence.
The nature of good dharmas, by means of its own essence, is the causal condition for all good dharmas, so there is no benefit to liberation.
If the nature of good dharmas is the cause of liberation, then this definitely abandons its own essence.
Why is this?
Because the established dharmas enter into their own essence.
If it is not so, then as previously stated, how can it not be accomplished by the liberation of non-good dharmas, and by the liberation of good dharmas?
If it is as previously stated, then this good dharma liberation is also not apart from conceptualization.
Therefore, one should know that all those dharmas, whether already arisen or not yet arisen, are the causes of the two liberations, and they are not produced.
Moreover, the verse says:
Already liberated cannot be spoken of, not yet liberated cannot be spoken of,
Liberated and not yet liberated are not spoken of, at the time of liberation there is also no speaking.
If this liberation is different, liberation would be endless;
If there is no liberation and yet liberation, all are liberated in this way.
The commentary says:
If one knows in this way, the path of liberation is also like this, fully as it arises and is spoken of.
The Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, have spoken this verse in the sutras:
Form dharmas are like a mass of foam, feelings are like floating bubbles,
Perceptions are the same as mirages that arise, volitional formations are like the characteristics of a plantain tree,
Consciousness is like an illusory dharma, manifesting the established dharmas,
Like a dream, like a reflected image, also the same as an echo.
It is also said that within all conditioned activities, all dharmas are without self, that is, without intrinsic nature.
One should know that the self spoken of here is a different name for the specific nature.
The true suchness of dharmas spoken of here is free from conceptual proliferation.
If one speaks of definitiveness, it is all a dharma of false grasping at deceptive falsehood.
Chapter 8: Contemplating the Agent and Action. Someone says:
The previous chapter spoke of refuting all dharmas, because the created and conditioned are not established, how can there be the unconditioned?
If one speaks thus, why is it contradictory to those scriptures?
As the World-Honored Buddha said in a sutra, there is a verse that goes:
One should cultivate good dharmas and practices, and not cultivate evil dharmas and practices;
The person who cultivates good dharmas and practices, is peaceful and blissful in the two worlds.
The meaning of this verse is that there is an agent, there is the dharma of action, and there is also a result.
What is said is true, as observed.
Why is it said to be conventional and not ultimate?
The treatise states:
Regarding all agents, whether they truly exist, do not truly exist, or both truly exist and do not truly exist in ultimate truth,
the actions they perform are also thus, whether they truly exist, do not truly exist, or both truly exist and do not truly exist.
For this reason, if the agent truly exists in relation to the action, then the action must also truly exist.
Thus, when mutually investigated, neither the agent nor the action truly exists.
If both true existence and non-true existence are both the case, then not even the slightest bit of a truly existent dharma can be found in ultimate truth.
If the agent truly exists, then there can be no truly existent action that can be obtained.
If the action truly exists, then the agent is also not in accord with it.
Moreover, a verse states:
If the agent truly exists, then it does not perform a truly existent action.
The commentary states:
If it is as stated, what can be believed?
Therefore, a subsequent verse states:
Because there is no real action, there is no distinction in action.
The commentary says:
If one stops good and bad actions, then what is done does not arise.
If there are two in what is done, then the doer also has two, and there is no doer in what is done.
This refutes the intrinsic characteristics of dharmas.
How is this so?
Therefore, the following verse says:
There is karma, but no doer.
The commentary says:
If one grasps at the arising of what is done in the doer and action, then this again becomes a contradiction with the intrinsic characteristics of dharmas.
Now, this should be refuted.
Moreover, a verse says:
Because there is no real what is done.
The commentary says:
Because there is no arising of the distinction in function.
If function is united with something, then what is done has two, and action also has two, and there is no action apart from what is done.
This refutes the intrinsic characteristics of dharmas.
Moreover, a verse says:
There is an agent but no action.
The explanation says:
If the action performed is separate from the functioning dharma, then the agent and the object of action are both mixed together.
This refutes the self-characteristic of dharmas.
Some people say:
If there is an agent and a functioning dharma, then there is the arising of action, which can be said to be a truly existent agent.
Because when the agent arises, the action is also not different, due to the combination of functioning, it also has no separate true existence.
This is without fault.
The treatise says:
What is called without fault?
Because the agent, action, and the dharma that is used, that which can be done and that which is to be done are all without action.
Here, if there is that which can be done and that which is done, the fault is as explained above.
If there is nothing to be done, that which can be done also does not exist, because it is apart from that which is to be done.
How is this?
There is the ability to create, the created, and the function of the created. This is so, and the same applies to other cases, as appropriate to refute.
This text is extensive now, fearing it is too much, I will stop here for now.
Again, someone says:
The creator and the created karma are unreal, this is possible, but the real existence of the creator should be appropriate.
Now, in order to refute what they say, therefore the verse says:
The creator also does not truly exist.
The commentary says:
If one considers the creator and created karma to be real, now this statement should also refute it.
Next, the verse says:
If the real creator exists, then the real created karma also exists;
The creator and created karma, both fall into being without a cause.
The commentary says:
This statement of creation is precisely the creator, this statement of what is created is precisely the karma.
If what is done is separate from the doer, there would be action to be done. In this way, there would only be a doer, but no time when what is done exists. There would be action without a cause.
If the doer and action fall into the nature of having no cause, then there is a one-sided fault. This should be examined.
Furthermore, a verse says:
If there is an effect without a cause, a cause is not reasonable.
The explanation says:
This word cause is called condition.
If a dharma arises with a cause, conditions are then included. If the cause has no substance, the present matter ceases. This is nonexistence. How can there be a meaning that includes conditions?
What is this again?
Therefore, a later verse says:
The doer and what is done have no substance, and action does not combine.
The explanation says:

If there is no object to be cut, such as firewood, then the cutter, the cutting instrument such as an axe, and the action of cutting would all be unrelated. To what would the action of cutting be applied?
Because it has no basis.
The agent and action would also lack substance.
How is this so?
Therefore, the following verse states:
If there is no dharma or non-dharma, then that which is produced would lack substance.
The commentary explains:
If the action of production is separated from the producer, then there would be no action.
Therefore, the following verse states:
Because dharma and non-dharma do not exist, the produced effect would also not exist.
The commentary explains:
What does this mean?
By this, there would be no evil destinies, good destinies, or the path of liberation, and the corresponding fruits would also not exist.
Moreover, a verse states:
Without fruits and without liberation, there would also be no path of rebirth and heaven;
Not only would the path of rebirth and heaven not exist, but the path of liberation would also not exist.
The commentary explains:
If so, then all the activities of all existents in the world would fall into the category of having no beneficial results.
The results of the world are like seeds and so forth. The functioning and transformation of activities are able to produce results. If they are without substance, then there is no beneficial result.
Some people say:
The meaning of what has been said, that the agent is not real, is possible.
That which is done by the activity is indeed real, because it is able to act, and there is no fault in this.
The treatise states:
How is this without fault?
Now, the agent is a different name for the cause, and the activity is the result.

Moreover, a dharma that is not a result does not have something done that is separate from the substance of the cause. In this way, if there is an agent and activity, then there is a cause and result that are combined and established.

Now, in this way, the activity is not different from the agent, and the agent is not different from the activity. Therefore, the activity that is done is also not separate, because the different causes lack intrinsic nature.
How is this known?
If a dharma has conditions and the means of accomplishment, then the nature of cause and effect is established. What is being said now is not unclear.
Some people say:
Because the agent is both real and unreal, and because the action is also both real and unreal.
The following verse answers their superior statement:
The agent is real and unreal, and does not perform both actions;
Existence and non-existence contradict each other, and there is no duality in one place.
The commentary says:
In one dharma, there is no combination of the two dharmas of existence and non-existence, because that is unreasonable.
In this way, the combination of agent and action is also unobtainable, because it contradicts reason.
Furthermore, the verse says:
The agent, action, and function, the real and unreal,
If attached, then faults arise, this reason is as previously stated.
The commentary says:
Herein, one should know that whether real or unreal, they are all spoken of in terms of mutual dependence.
Therefore, the following verse says:
What is done is real and unreal, both real and unreal;
The doer and the action, this cause is as explained before.
The doer and all that is done, is neither real nor unreal;
One should know that action is also thus, this cause is as explained before.
What is done in reality is nonexistent, what is done unreal has no cause;
Existence and nonexistence contradict each other, how can there be two in one place?
The commentary says:
The three kinds of mutual dependence spoken of here are as explained in the doctrine of arising.
Therefore, one should know that the World-Honored Buddha does not completely deny the doer, the action, and all activity in all cases. This does not fall into the fault of having no cause.
The treatise states:
This is truly without fault.
I also do not say that the doer and that action do not exist.
Why is it so?
I wish to illustrate that the agent and action are mutually established.
Moreover, the verse says:
Based on the agent there is action, based on action there is the agent.
The commentary says:

One should know that in this context, all the transformations and designations are without self-nature. The agent and action, whether accomplished or not, whether apart from existence or non-existence, prove the meaning in the middle, which is obtained in the conventional.
Therefore, the verse below says:
The conventional eliminates difference, I see the characteristics of accomplishment.
The commentary says:
If someone says this contradicts the scriptures, their reason is not established.
An outsider says:
In the ultimate truth there is an agent.
Why is it so?
Because the Buddha said there is that which can grasp and that which is grasped.
The treatise says:
Now, in order to refute that statement, it is said that in those various activities there is that which can grasp.
If the two dharmas of the grasper and the grasped are not destroyed, then the doer and the follower are also inseparable.
In this way, one should know that the grasper and the grasped mutually include each other.

Therefore, based on this, the doer exists due to the cause of the action, and the action exists due to the cause of the doer. Therefore, based on the grasper, there is the grasped, and because of the grasped, there is the grasper. This is not the ultimate truth.
Now, what is the case?
Is there a negation of the doer and the action apart from that?
Here, the meaning of the cause of what is done, if it negates the doer and the action, then the grasper and the grasped should also be separated from it.
Next, a verse says:
If in the ultimate truth, there is a doer and an action,
Then the grasper and the grasped should also be negated.
The meaning of the doer, the action, and so forth, is like this;
The meaning of the mutual cause of other dharmas, oneself, and others should be observed.
The commentary says:
If there are effects or causes, characteristics or the characterized, co-arising or non-co-arising, etc., the two dharmas of cause and effect have an obtained substance.
If it is said there is a cause, then it falls into the category of effects.
Like that which is produced, if there is a meaning that can be grasped, then it has an inherent nature.
If it does not exist, then it is not produced.
If dharmas such as form have no meaning that can be grasped, then they have no substance that can be observed, let alone cause and effect being apart from their own substance and having the ability.
If apart from their own substance they have the ability, then there is contradiction in what is obtained, just as if apart from the lump of clay there can be a pot.
The arising in the dharmas of the state of substance is called the production of the pot from the lump of clay, like the water in the pot.
Because there is no separate state nature, and also because the pot is not like wood, and also because the state of the lump of clay is not said to have a pot, just like a separate pot.
If by its own power there is something obtained, this is contradictory.

If the dharmas of pleasure, etc. have powerful ability as causes, then there are the dharmas of pleasure, etc. as effects. Because pleasure, etc. exist, then the distinctions of pleasure, etc. are produced.
Here, what is said to be obtained, this is also said to be without contradicting any dharmas.
If apart from cause and effect there is powerful ability to say what is accomplished, then in this way it is certain that they lack the ability to accomplish cause and effect.
This either accomplishes an inverted conceptual attachment, or it accomplishes a definite non-common cause, because in the midst of contradiction apart from cause there is no substance.
If the non-common cause is not accomplished in one direction,
if cause and effect are united, then the substance has a nature.
